revision.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox airline | airline=Connect Air | image= | IATA= | ICAO= | callsign= | founded= | commenced=2004 | ceased=2008 | bases=[[EuroAirport Basel-Mulhouse-Freiburg]] | fleet_size=[[ATR 72|ATR 72-500]] | destinations= | headquarters=[[Basel]], [[Switzerland]] }} '''Connect Air''' was an [[airline]] based in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]]. It was established in 2004 and was a start-up airline planning services to various cities in [[Europe]] using a fleet of [[ATR 72|ATR 72-500]] aircraft. Its main base was [[EuroAirport Basel-Mulhouse-Freiburg]]. It ceased operations in mid-2008. {{Airlines of Switzerland}} [[Category:Defunct airlines of Switzerland]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2004]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2008]] {{Europe-airline-stub}} {{Switzerland-company-stub}} {{Switzerland-stub}}

{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=January 2016}}{{prose|date=January 2016}}}}
'''Delft Jewelry''' is the generic name for [[jewelry]] featuring Dutch (Netherlands) miniature [[Delftware]] medallions or brooch panels in a silver setting.<ref name=verwoerdceramics>{{cite web|url=http://verwoerdceramics.com/delft|title=Verwoerd Ceramics Online|author=Verwoerd Ceramics Online|publisher=}}</ref> Delft jewelry includes necklaces, pendants, earrings, brooches, bracelets, rings, and cufflinks. The Delft panels are usually made of pottery and decorated with a blue and white windmill landscape. The silver setting often has the form of silver [[filigree]]. Delft jewelry has been made in the Netherlands since c.1879.<ref>Erickson, Rick - Royal Delft: a guide to De Porceleyne Fles, p.167 - Schiffer Publishing 2003</ref> It flourished especially in the decades after WW2 as a result of demand from the Dutch tourist industry. That era saw the emergence of three specialist producers of Delft medallions. For most other Delftware factories however, brooch panels have been a relatively small side product.
The main producers of Delft brooch panels as a side product have been:<ref name=verwoerdceramics/> * [[De Koninklijke Porceleyne Fles]], Delft * Plateelbakkerij Delft, Amsterdam/Hilversum * Plateelbakkerij Schoonhoven, Schoonhoven * Plateelbakkerij en Pijpenfabrieken Zenith, Gouda<ref>Tasman, Ron - The Gouda Pottery Book, PZH, p. 582 - Christchurch (NZ) 2007</ref> * Goedewaagen's Hollandse Pijpen- en Aardewerkfabrieken, Gouda
The main specialist producers of Delft brooch panels have been: *Atelier Van Katwijk, Gouda - established in 1946 by Frans van Katwijk<ref>De Jonge, Leendert - Frans van Katwijk, pp 66-75, p 100 - Zwolle 2009</ref> *Keramiekatelier C.Verwoerd, Gouda - established in 1949 by [[Cornelis Verwoerd]] *Kunstatelier Porceletti, Gouda - established in c.1955 by Dick Olthuysen
Delft brooch panels are usually set in silver. The emergence of specialist producers of Delft jewelry in Gouda, Netherlands, was greatly helped by the presence of an important silversmithing community in the nearby town of [[Schoonhoven]]. Zenith Gouda and Goedewaagen Gouda have been suppliers of Delft medallions to silversmith H. Hooykaas of Schoonhoven. Van Katwijk, Verwoerd, and Porceletti have been suppliers of Delft brooch panels to silversmith G.J. Van den Bergh Jr. Several other Schoonhoven silversmiths have been involved in the production of Delft jewelry as well.<ref name=verwoerdceramics/>
<gallery> Porceleyne Fles ships brooch 1892.jpg|Ships brooch by De Porceleyne Fles 1892
Zenith Gouda brooch c.1939.jpg|Windmill brooch by Zenith Gouda c.1939
Schoonhoven brooch c.1946.jpg|Winter windmill brooch by PB Schoonhoven c.1946
Van Katwijk brooch c.1950.jpg|Winter windmill brooch by Van Katwijk c.1950
Verwoerd brooch c.1950.jpg|Windmill brooch by Verwoerd c.1950
Porceletti transfer print.jpg|Transfer printed brooch panel by Porceletti c.1960-2001 </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Dutch pottery]] [[Category:Ceramics manufacturers of the Netherlands]]
{{Netherlands-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Sør-Hålogaland |local = Sør-Hålogaland bispedømme |image = Bodø domkirke.jpg |caption = View of Bodø Cathedral |country = [[Norway]] |territory = [[Nordland]] |denomination = [[Church of Norway]] |established = 1952 |bishop = [[Ann-Helen Fjeldstad Jusnes]] |cathedral = [[Bodø Cathedral]] |deaneries = Bodø domprosti, Lofoten, Ofoten, Vesterålen, Salten, Nord-Helgeland, Indre Helgeland, Sør-Helgeland |parishes = 96 |members = 198,420 |map = Dioceses Church of Norway.svg |map_caption = Location of Sør-Hålogaland diocese |website = http://www.kirken.no/sor-haalogaland |footnotes = Reference{{cite web|url=http://snl.no/S%C3%B8r-H%C3%A5logaland_bisped%C3%B8mme|title=Sør-Hålogaland bispedømme|author=Store norske leksikon|authorlink=Store norske leksikon|language=Norwegian|accessdate=2011-10-28}} }} '''Sør-Hålogaland''' is a [[diocese]] in the [[Church of Norway]]. The Diocese covers the Lutheran [[Church of Norway]] churches located within [[Nordland]] county in [[Norway]]. The diocese is headquartered in the [[Bodø (town)|town of Bodø]] at [[Bodø Cathedral]], the seat of the presiding Bishop [[Ann-Helen Fjeldstad Jusnes]] (since 2015). The diocese is divided into eight [[deanery|deaneries]] {{lang|no|(prosti)}}. ==History== In 1952, the old [[Diocese of Hålogaland]] (which covered all of [[Northern Norway]]) was split into two: the Diocese of Sør-Hålogaland (Nordland county) and the [[Diocese of Nord-Hålogaland]] ([[Troms]], [[Finnmark]], and [[Svalbard]]). ==Bishops== The bishops of Sør-Hålogaland since its creation in 1952: *1952–1959: [[Wollert Krohn-Hansen]] *1959–1969: [[Hans Edvard Wisløff]] *1969–1982: [[Bjarne Odd Weider]] *1982–1992: [[Fredrik Grønningsæter]] *1992–2006: [[Øystein Ingar Larsen]] *2007-2015: [[Tor Berger Jørgensen]] *Since 2015: [[Ann-Helen Fjeldstad Jusnes]] ==Cathedral== {{main|Bodø Cathedral}} The old church in Bodø was destroyed during [[World War II]], and after the war plans were made to replace the church and make it the cathedral for the new diocese. The foundation stone was laid in 1954 and was consecrated by Bishop [[Wollert Krohn-Hansen]] in 1956. There is also a memorial to those who died in Bodø during the [[Second World War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ub.uit.no/baser/arkinord/categories.php?cat_id=180&l=norwegian|title=Bodø Cathedral|publisher=Arkitekturguide Nordnorge og Svalbard}} ==Structure== The Diocese of Sør-Hålogaland is divided into eight [[deanery|deaneries]] ({{lang-no|prosti}}). Each one corresponds to several municipalities in the diocese. Each municipality is further divided into one or more [[parish]]es which each contain one or more congregations. See each municipality below for lists of churches and parishes within them. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Deanery (''prosti'') !! Municipalities !! Diocese Map |- |'''Bodø domprosti'''
(Map: lower blue)||[[Bodø]], [[Gildeskål]], [[Meløy]], [[Røst]], [[Værøy]]||rowspan="8"|[[File:Prostier i Nordland.svg|200px]] |- |'''Lofoten prosti'''
(Map: upper green)||[[Flakstad]], [[Moskenes]], [[Vestvågøy]], [[Vågan]] |- |'''Vesterålen prosti'''
(Map: upper blue)||[[Andøy]], [[Bø, Nordland|Bø]], [[Hadsel]], [[Sortland]], [[Øksnes]] |- |'''Ofoten prosti'''
(Map: red)||[[Ballangen]], [[Evenes]], [[Hamarøy]], [[Lødingen]], [[Narvik]], [[Tjeldsund]], [[Tysfjord]] |- |'''Salten prosti'''
(Map: upper yellow)||[[Beiarn]], [[Fauske]], [[Saltdal]], [[Steigen]], [[Sørfold]] |- |'''Nord-Helgeland prosti'''
(Map: light blue)||[[Alstahaug]], [[Dønna]], [[Herøy, Nordland|Herøy]], [[Leirfjord]], [[Lurøy]], [[Nesna]], [[Rødøy]], [[Træna]] |- |'''Indre Helgeland prosti'''
(Map: lower green)||[[Grane, Nordland|Grane]], [[Hattfjelldal]], [[Hemnes]], [[Rana, Norway|Rana]], [[Vefsn]] |- |'''Sør-Helgeland prosti'''
(Map: lower yellow)||[[Bindal]], [[Brønnøy]], [[Sømna]], [[Vega, Norway|Vega]], [[Vevelstad]] |} {{see also|List of churches in Nordland}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kirken.bodo.no/wips/1288225687/ Church of Norway in Bodø ] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110723211804/http://webster.hibo.no/kantun/bib/Katedr0.htm Bodø Cathedral] {{Bishops of Norway}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Diocese of Sor-Haalogaland}} [[Category:Church of Norway dioceses|Sor-Haalogaland]] [[Category:Nordland]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1952]] [[Category:1952 establishments in Norway]] [[Category:Organisations based in Bodø]] {{Norway-stub}} {{Lutheran-stub}}

{{Infobox TV channel| |name = ERT World |logofile = ERT World.svg |logosize = 200px |launch = 1996
3 May 2016 (relaunch) |closed date = |owner = [[Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation|ERT]] |former names = ERT Sat (1996-2006) |sister names = [[ERT1]]
[[ERT2]]
[[ERT3]]
[[ERT HD]] |picture format = [[576i]] ([[16:9]] [[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]) |web = [https://program.ert.gr/ErtWorld/ ERT World] |country = [[Greece]] |language = Greek
English |headquarters = [[Broadcasting House (Athens)]], [[Greece]] |broadcast area = '''[[Europe]]'''
'''[[North America]]'''
'''[[South America]]'''
'''[[Africa]]'''
'''[[Australia]]'''
'''[[New Zealand]]'''
'''[[Asia]]''' and '''[[Oceania]]''' |network_type = [[Cable television|Cable]] and [[Satellite]] [[television network]]| | sat serv 1 = [[Hot Bird 13B]] (Europe, Middle East, North Africa) | sat chan 1 = 11623 V / 27500 / 3/4 | sat serv 2 = | sat chan 2 = | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | cable serv 2 = | cable chan 2 = | cable serv 3 = | cable chan 3 = | iptv serv 1 = | iptv chan 1 = | iptv serv 2 = | iptv chan 2 = | online serv 1 = ERT WebTV | online chan 1 = [http://webtv.ert.gr/ertworld-live/ Watch live] }} '''ERT World''' (formerly '''ERT SAT''') is an internationally broadcast Greek-language channel run by [[Greece]]'s national broadcaster [[Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation]] (ERT). Programming includes a mix of news, discussion-based programmes, drama, documentaries, entertainment shows as well as sports coverage including live games from Greece's top soccer league, [[Superleague Greece]]. As of June 12, 2013, was disestablished under an order of the Greek Government, as part of austerity measures, along with all of ERT's former TV and radio channels; ET1, NET, ET3, ERT World and the radios ceased to operate from the morning of Wednesday 12 June. As of 3 May 2016, ERT world broadcasts again on Europe. ERT World created a special program consisting of the best programmes from the three national channels, ERT1, ERT2 and ERT3, and its own specialized programs targeted at the global promotion of Greece. It also used to air programs from [[Cyprus Broadcasting Corporation]] (the [[Cyprus|Cypriot]] public broadcaster) but discontinued the practice. Programming is split into two zones - weekday and weekend. On weekdays one can find standard news and information as well as some entertainment shows. On the weekend the focus is mainly on entertainment and sports. In early 2006, the Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation revealed that ERT SAT would be undergoing a major overhaul to allow it to better meet the needs of Greeks abroad. Among the changes are new programmes designed specifically for the ''Omogeneia'' (Greek [[expatriate]]s) and a localized schedule to serve each of the newly designated program 'zones' - North America, Europe/Africa and Asia/Australia. The new program zones were to be launched in the fall of 2006 but as of March 2013 had yet to materialize as the channel still aired programs according to local time in Greece ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]+2). In August 2010, ERT announced that they had initiated a public bidding process to award the worldwide distribution rights for ERT World. The current rights holder, Comart Telecom declined to renew their agreement with ERT and on August 30, 2010 it was announced that PCCW Global would be awarded the distribution rights temporarily for 1 year until the bidding process was completed and a decision made on the rights holder. As of March 2013, the distribution rights are held by KBI Implus Hellas.[http://www.kbihellas.com/ KBI Implus Hellas] On 11 June 2013, the channel and all the channels of the ERT group were brutally cut shortly before 11 pm (local time). If the terrestrial channels (ERT1, ERT2 and ERT3) resume their broadcasts on 11 June 2015, it is still almost a year before the satellite version of Greek public television resumes broadcasting on the Hot Bird satellite on 3 May 2016 in Europe. ==Programming== ===Original ERT World programming=== *''Apo Tin Australia Me Agapi'' - weekly magazine, features news and stories about the Greek diaspora in Australia. Hosted by Alekos Markellos & Emma Emmanuel. *''Odysseia'' (Odyssey) - new program created specifically for '''ERT World''', deals with the Omogenia. Features community news from various Greek communities around the world, issues regarding the initiatives and events of the diaspora, problems facing those living abroad regarding connecting with the homeland and live reports from cities and communities of the Apodimos Ellinismos. Hosted by Dora Anagnostopoulou. *''Elliniko Panorama'' (Hellenic Panorama) - newsmagazine designed specifically for viewers of ERT World that aims to present to viewers the face of Hellenism. A look at the new generation and how they are shaping the Greece of tomorrow, discussion with Hellenes abroad and reports on key individuals. Now in its 4th year, hosted by Irini Nikolopoulou. *''NEWS4U'' - daily English language news bulletin *''Tekmiria Ellinismou'' - documentary series ===From ET3=== *''Αlithina Senaria'' - informative series that takes the viewer around the world to meet people who excel in their respective jobs. From a businessman on Wall Street to a shepherd in Pindos, from an acclaimed journalist to a hermit in Pilios, these are fascinating people with a story to tell. This program is now in its ninth year and has been the most watched show on ET-3 since its inception. It is hosted by Nikos Aslanidis. *''Anikhnéfsis'' - news magazine with focus on the Balkan region and the countries that comprise it. It gives an in depth look at the culture, history and people of this region. Hosted by Pantelis Savvidis. *''[[Diaspora]]'' - a series that focuses on bridging the gap between Greeks living abroad and Greece. It gives a voice to the ''omogenia'', to tell about their way of life, the problems they face, stories about their experiences and more. This show that will inform and entertain viewers the world around is hosted by Xrusa Samou. ==Logos== Image:ERT Sat (Original).jpg|Original ERT Sat logo, 1996-2000 Image:ERT Sat (Second).png|ERT Sat logo used from 2000 to 2006 Image:ERT Sat.png|ERT Sat logo (2006) Image:ERT_World.svg|ERT World logo used from 2006–2013 and again since its re-launching on 2016. This logo changed the new look from 2008. ==See also== *[[ERT World (Canada)|ERT World Canada]] *[[Cyprus Broadcasting Corporation]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation}} {{Television in Greece}} [[Category:Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation]] [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Television channels in Greece]] [[Category:Greek-language television stations]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1996]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Greece]] [[Category:Propaganda television broadcasts]]

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Hayat Production]] closed as soft delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Erato |image = |caption = |image_size = |background = group_or_band |alias = |origin = [[Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina]] |genre = [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Pop music|pop]] |years_active = 1999–2009 |label = JRTVSB&H, Hayat Production |associated_acts = |website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20060620042353/http://www.erato.ba/ Erato.ba] |current_members = Aida Terzić (nee Jašarević)
[[Dalal Midhat-Talakić]] |past_members = }} '''Erato''' was a [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian]] [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] duo consisting of Aida Jašarević and [[Dalal Midhat]]. The band began with five girls but after three members quit due to lack of singing ability, the band became a duo with Jašarević and Midhat continuing on. The band has released two albums; Backstage (2003) and Make Up (2005).{{cite web|title=Erato (duo) |url=http://www.xklsv.org/viewwiki.php?title=Erato%20(duo) |publisher=xklsv.org |accessdate=3 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103215755/http://www.xklsv.org/viewwiki.php?title=Erato%20(duo) |archivedate=January 3, 2014 }} {{cite web|title=Erato - Ni jedna suza |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RWp11vgG3iI |publisher=youtube.com |accessdate=3 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140620071239/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RWp11vgG3iI |archivedate=June 20, 2014 }} {{cite web|title=Erato Music Videos|url=http://www.ovguide.com/erato-9202a8c04000641f8000000000dedbd5|publisher=ovguide.com|accessdate=3 January 2014}} The duo's name comes from [[Erato|the muse]]. In October 2008, the duo reached the Bosnian Top 10{{cn|date=September 2014}} with "Putujemo Snovima", a track that featured Croatian singer [[Jacques Houdek]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Erato}} [[Category:Pop music duos]] [[Category:Contemporary R&B duos]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina musical groups]] [[Category:Hayat Production artists]] {{europe-band-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=January 2017}}
'''Geopolitical imaginations''' are constructed views of the world that reflect the vision of a place’s, a country’s or a society’s role within world politics. <ref>Güney, Aylin & Gökcan Fulya, [“Greater Middle East as a ‘Modern’ Geopolitical Imagination in the American Foreign Policy”], ''Geopolitics'', 2010. 15 (1): 22-38.</ref> Geopolitical imaginations are constituted by shared assumptions and representations of power relations and conflicts in world politics within a certain geographical territory. <ref>Latham, Andrew A., [“China in the Contemporary American Geopolitical Imagination”], ''Asian Affairs: An American Review.'', 2001. 28(3): 138-145.</ref> By critically analyzing how and why these imaginations are constructed, it is possible to reveal underlying power relations and to get a better understanding of various conflicts. Therefore, geopolitical imaginations are closely connected to the academic field of critical geopolitics. <ref>Toal, Gerard, [“Critical geopolitics: The politics of writing global space. Vol. 6”], '' University of Minnesota Press'', 1996.</ref>
== Concept == Geopolitical imaginations are composed of the representation of a country’s territorial limits and its geopolitical code which is “[...] a set of strategic assumptions that a government makes about other states”. <ref>Güney, Aylin & Gökcan Fulya, [“Greater Middle East as a ‘Modern’ Geopolitical Imagination in the American Foreign Policy”], ''Geopolitics'', 2010. 15 (1): 22-38.</ref> These so-called geopolitical codes are based on [[national identity]] (particularly in ‘them’ and ‘us’ distinctions), emotional attachment to a place as well as [[National myth|national myths]]. <ref>Güney, Aylin & Gökcan Fulya, [“Greater Middle East as a ‘Modern’ Geopolitical Imagination in the American Foreign Policy”], ''Geopolitics'', 2010. 15 (1): 22-38.</ref> Geopolitical imaginations provide the legitimisation for geopolitical actions or certain positions in foreign and domestic policy. <ref>Latham, Andrew A., [“China in the Contemporary American Geopolitical Imagination”], ''Asian Affairs: An American Review.'', 2001. 28(3): 138-145.</ref> Geopolitical imaginations are reflections of current discourses and therefore they are not fixed but rather vary over time and in different societies. Research has primarily analyzed geopolitical imaginations of European and North American countries, ignoring the fact that in other socio-political contexts there exist different ‘non-western’ geopolitical imaginations. <ref>Sharp, Joanne, ["”A subaltern critical geopolitics of the war on terror: Postcolonial security in Tanzania”"], ''Geoforum'', 2011. 42: 297–305.</ref>
== Hegemonic geopolitical imaginations in history == The view of the world as two polarizing ideological blocs ([[Western Bloc|western]] and [[eastern bloc]]) is a geopolitical imagination which was dominant during time of the [[Cold War]]. Designations such as the [[Iron Curtain]] (the boundary between the bipolar powers) helped to justify certain politics and policies, e.g. in the United States in foreign policy by [[containment]] (a military strategy to stop the expansion of the ‘enemy’) or in domestic policy with the expansion of [[homeland security]] which enforced technologies of control and disciplining. <ref>Reuber, Paul, ["Politische Geographie"], ''Paderborn: Ferdinand Schöning'', 2012.</ref> [[Samuel P. Huntington]] made a draft of a fragmented conflicted world order. In his popular hypothesis called ”[[The Clash of Civilizations]]” (1996), he divided the world map geographically into rigid cultural entities, such as the Western bloc, the Islamic bloc or the African bloc, and proclaimed that the next major conflict will occur between these different cultures. <ref>Reuber, Paul, ["Politische Geographie"], ''Paderborn: Ferdinand Schöning'', 2012.</ref> In the 21st century, “hegemonic geographical imaginations are dominated by the affective geopolitics of the [[War on Terror]]”. <ref>Sharp, Joanne, ["”A subaltern critical geopolitics of the war on terror: Postcolonial security in Tanzania”"], ''Geoforum'', 2011. 42: 297–305.</ref> This has been a consequence of the synthesis between the Clash of Civilizations, the terror attacks of 9/11 and the following designations of [[rogue states]] (states which have been blamed for threatening the world peace) and the [[axis of evil]] (states which have been accused of supporting terrorism and aspiring to weapons of mass destruction). <ref>Reuber, Paul, ["Politische Geographie"], ''Paderborn: Ferdinand Schöning'', 2012.</ref>
== See also == [[Critical geopolitics|Critical Geopolitics]]
[[Geopolitics]]
[[Imagined geographies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
* * * *
[[Category:Geopolitics]] [[Category:Geopolitical terminology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Jeudan | logo = Jeudan logo.jpg | type = A/s | predecessor = | successor = | founder = | defunct = | fate = | area_served = Denmark | key_people = Per Wetke Hallgren <small>([[chief executive officer|CEO]]), Jørgen Tandrup <small>([[Chairman]])</small> | industry = Property | genre = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.jeudan.dk/ www.jeudan.dk] | footnotes = | intl = | foundation = 1898 | location_city = [[Copenhagen]] | location_country = Denmark | location = | locations = }} '''Jeudan''' is the largest listed real estate company in [[Denmark]]. It is the largest private real estate investment company in the country and its activities also comprise property and facility management. The company is headquartered in [[Prince William Mansion, Copenhagen|Prince William Mansion]] in [[Copenhagen]].
==History== The company was founded in 1898. In 1999, jeuDAN merged with Ejendomsselskabet EEC under the name Jeudan. In 2000, Jeudan acquired a 27.5 % share of Ejendomsselskabet Norden with the intension of merging the two companies but all shares was instead sold to a group of Danish pension funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://byensejendom.dk/article/norden-aktier-gav-rekordoverskud-hos-jeudan-8911|title=JeudNorden-aktier gav rekordoverskud hos Jeudan|publisher=Byens Ejendomme|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref> In 2009, Jeudan acquired Landic Properties Denmark (formerly Atlas Ehendomme) for DKK 2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business.dk/investor/jeudan-koeber-atlas-ejendomme-for-2-milliarder-kr|title=Jeudan køber Atlas Ehendomme for 2 milliarder kr.|publisher=Berlingske|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> In October 2014, it took over the position as the largest real estate investment company in Denmark from [[DADES]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/96052/artikel.html?hl=RGFkZXM,|title=Jeudan er nu landets største ejendomsselskab|publisher=[[Dagbladet Børsen]]|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref>
==Ownership== As of January 2014, [[William Demant|William Demant Invest]] owned 41.6 % and [[Augustinus Fonden|Chr. Augustinus Fabrikker]] owned 29.9 % of the shares in the company and Nesdu and the company's owner, Jens Erik Udsen, owned an 11 % share.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://byensejendom.dk/article/chr-augustinus-fabrikker-udvider-aktieportefoljen-i-jeudan-11261|title=Chr. Augustinus Fabrikker udvider aktieporteføljen I Jeudan|publisher=[[Dagbladet Børsen]]|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref>
==Portfolio== Jeudan owns Københavns Torvehaller, the covered market on [[Israels Plads]] in Copenhagen.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.jeudan.dk/ Official website]
[[Category:Real estate companies of Denmark]] [[Category:Companies based in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Real estate companies established in 1898]] [[Category:Danish companies established in 1898]]
{{Denmark-stub}} {{company-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ecole nationale de Police, Cotonou, Bénin.JPG|thumb|Courtyard of the Benin national police school, in the Zongo-Nima district of Cotonou.]]
As in many other countries with a [[French colonial empire|French colonial]] heritage, '''[[law enforcement]] in [[Benin]]''' is a responsibility primarily shared by a [[gendarmerie]] and a [[police]] force.
==Police== The '''Police of the Republic of Benin''' ({{lang-fr|Police Republicaine du Bénin}}) is under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of the Interior, Public Security and Religious Affairs (MISPC, {{lang-fr|Ministère de l’Intérieur, de la Sécurité publique et des Cultes}}).<ref name=interpolbenin>{{cite web|title=Bénin|url=http://www.interpol.int/fr/Pays-membres/Afrique/B%C3%A9nin|website=INTERPOL|publisher=INTERPOL|accessdate=19 June 2015|language=French}}</ref> The country is divided into six '''directions départementales'''. Police training is conducted at the national police school in [[Cotonou]].
==Gendarmerie== The '''Gendarmerie nationale béninoise''' has both military and police roles. Due to its military status, the gendarmerie answers to the Ministry of Defence. It is headquartered in [[Porto-Novo]]. As a police force, it has administrative and judiciary police powers. It operates both in territorial units, responsible for defined areas, and mobile units, which can be dispatched. Overall, it has jurisdiction in nearly 90% of the country's territory.
==Other forces== In addition to the police and gendarmerie, law enforcement is provided by several forces, including [[customs]] (''les Douanes''), [[game warden]]s (''les Eaux et forêts'') and the ''Unité mixte de contrôle des conteneurs'' (UMCC).
==Joint container inspection unit== The '''Unité mixte de contrôle des conteneurs'' includes staff from the ''Police'', ''Gendarmerie'', ''Douanes'', and ''Eaux et forêts''. Stationed in the harbour of Cotonou, it inspects [[Shipping container|containers]] in order to prevent the shipping of prohibited items such as drugs, weapons and counterfeit goods.<ref name=interpolbenin />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== # World Police Encyclopedia, ed. by Dilip K. Das & Michael Palmiotto published by Taylor & Francis. 2004, # World Encyclopedia of Police Forces and Correctional Systems,second edition, Gale., 2006 # Sullivan, Larry E. Encyclopedia of Law Enforcement. Thousand Oaks: Sage Publications, 2005.
{{Benin topics}} {{Africa topic|Law enforcement in}}
[[Category:Law enforcement in Benin|*]]
{{Benin-stub}} {{Africa-law-stub}}

{{for|the Timorese language Makua|Makuv'a language}} {{Infobox language family |name=Makua |altname=Makhuwa |region = [[Mozambique]] |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] |fam5=[[Southern Bantu]] |child1=Makhuwa |child2=Koti, Sakati |child3=Lomwe |child4=Cuabo–Maindo |child5=Moniga |glotto=maku1247 |glottorefname=Makua (P.30) }}
The '''Makua''' or '''Makhuwa''' languages are a branch of [[Bantu languages]] spoken primarily in [[Mozambique]].
==Name== The name ''Makua (Macua)'', more precisely ''Makhuwa'', is used on three levels. Some sources distinguish these with differences in spelling 'Makua' vs. 'Makhuwa', but they are not consistent. #Central Makhuwa, or "Makhuwa-Makhuwana", the [[prestige dialect]] and the basis of the national language of [[Mozambique]] #The [[Makhuwa language]], including various dialects which also go by the name ''Makhuwa''; sometimes called 'core' or 'nuclear' Makua, but this is not consistent #Closely related languages which often have their own names, such as [[Lomwe language|Lomwe]] (also known as Western Makua)
==Classification== Makhuwa is assigned to Zone P of the [[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages]]. With the classification of the other Zone-P languages as [[Rufiji–Ruvuma languages|Rufiji–Ruvuma]], Makhuwa becomes essentially synonymous with Zone P. However, the zones are geographic rather than genealogical clades. The closest relatives of the Makhuwa branch are not clear, but some classifications place them with the [[Nyasa languages|Nyasa]] and [[Southern Bantu languages]]. *[[Makhuwa language|Makhuwa]] (Core Makhuwa, including dialects Makhuwa-Meetto, Makhuwa-Shirima, Makhuwa-Marrevone, etc.) *[[Koti language|Koti]] *[[Sakati language|Sakati]] *[[Lomwe language|Lomwe]] (including Ngulu dialect) *[[Chuwabu language|Chuwabu]] *[[Moniga language|Moniga]]
The core languages, and beyond, have minimal [[mutual intelligibility]].
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Makua Languages}} [[Category:Makua languages| ]]
{{Bantu-lang-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Diocese of Equilio''' ({{lang-la|Dioecesis Equilium}}) was a Roman Catholic ecclesiastical territory in the town of [[Equilio]] the [[province of Venice]], [[Italy]].<ref name=CathHierEquilio>[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/de521.html "Diocese of Equilio"] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved July 2, 2016{{Self-published source|date=December 2016}}</ref><ref name=GCathEquilio>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/former/t0721.htm "Titular Episcopal See of Equilio"] ''GCatholic.org''. Gabriel Chow. Retrieved July 2, 2016</ref> It was suppressed in 1466 to the [[Patriarchate of Venice]].<ref name=GCathEquilio />
==History== *800: Erected as Diocese of Equilio<ref name=GCathEquilio /> *1466: Suppressed to the Patriarchate of Venice<ref name=GCathEquilio /> *1966: Restored as the Titular Episcopal See of Equilio<ref name=GCathEquilio />
==Ordinaries== *[[Antonio Bono]] (Bon) (6 Feb 1443 - 1451 Died) *[[Andreas Bono]] (15 Nov 1451 - 1466 Died)
==See also== *[[Catholic Church in Italy]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{coord missing|Italy}} {{Subject bar |portal1= Catholicism |portal2= Italy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Equilio, Roman Catholic Diocese of}} [[Category:Former Roman Catholic dioceses in Italy]]
{{Italy-RC-diocese-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} The '''Small Countries Financial Management Centre''' is a charity <ref>Isle of Man Government Index of Registered Charities http://www.gov.im/registries/courts/charities/index.xml Accessed 25 April 2011</ref> which was established in June 2009. It is, in effect, a "micro multilateral" body whose purpose is to help to contribute to the growth and prosperity of small states through capacity building in the government financial sector.<ref>9 July 2010 IFC (International Finance Centre) - Initiative is helping development of small countries http://www.ifcfeed.com/isle-of-man-articles/Initiative-is-helping-development-of-small-countries.aspx {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008212010/http://www.ifcfeed.com/isle-of-man-articles/Initiative-is-helping-development-of-small-countries.aspx# |date=8 October 2011 }} Accessed 20 April 2011</ref>
The countries involved (mainly those with a population of under 1.5 million) are:<ref>October 2010 Paul Melly – Developing Leaders magazine - Big Issues for Small Countries Issue 2</ref><ref>16 August 2009 All Business - John C Bersia – Small Countries Need a Helping Hand http://www.allbusiness.com/crime-law-enforcement-corrections/human-rights/12637343-1.html</ref>
Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Belize, Bhutan, Botswana, Cook Islands, Dominica, Fiji, The Gambia, Grenada, Jamaica, Kiribati, Lesotho, Maldives, Marshall Islands, Mauritius, Montenegro, Namibia, St Kitts and Nevis, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Lucia, Seychelles, Timor-Leste, Tonga, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Swaziland, Vanuatu.
The Centre is located at the [[Isle of Man International Business School]]. Its Executive Director <ref>9 July 2010 IFC (International Finance Centre) - Initiative is helping development of small countries http://www.ifcfeed.com/isle-of-man-articles/Initiative-is-helping-development-of-small-countries.aspx {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008212010/http://www.ifcfeed.com/isle-of-man-articles/Initiative-is-helping-development-of-small-countries.aspx# |date=8 October 2011 }} Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> is a former World Bank Chief Spokesman Tim Cullen MBE.<ref>http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/c/13177/Timothy%20William%20Brian%20%28Tim%29%20CULLEN.aspx Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> Cullen, a Commissioner on the Isle of Man Financial Supervision Commission <ref>2001 Isle of Man Government - New Financial Supervision Commission Board announced - http://www.gov.im/infocentre/archived_releases/PR_fsc_01/newBoard.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009060621/http://www.gov.im/infocentre/archived_releases/PR_fsc_01/newBoard.html# |date=9 October 2012 }} Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> and an Associate Fellow at Oxford University's [[Said Business School]] <ref>http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/c/13177/Timothy%20William%20Brian%20%28Tim%29%20CULLEN.aspx Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> was instrumental in creating the Centre’s Small Countries Financial Management Programme (SCFMP), an initiative which brings together officials from an extremely diverse range of small countries. Participants come from finance ministries, central banks and regulatory bodies.<ref>9 July 2010 Isle of Man News www.iomguide.com/news/general-news.php?story=105966 Accessed 25 April 2011</ref> The programme offers a support mechanism through which they can exchange ideas, share their own countries’ challenges and give each other practical assistance. The acquisition of negotiation skills is a priority, and participants learn from leading practitioners and professors.<ref>Isle of Man Treasury – The Small Countries Financial Management {{cite web |url=http://www.gov.im/treasury/scfmc/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608025332/http://www.gov.im/treasury/scfmc/ |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Accessed 19 April 2011</ref>
Partners of the Centre include the [[Isle of Man Government]],<ref>14 October 2008 IOM News article Treasury Minister Meets Financial Leaders in Washington {{cite web |url=http://www.gov.im/lib/news/cso/treasuryminister.xml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009061830/http://www.gov.im/lib/news/cso/treasuryminister.xml |archivedate=9 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> the [[World Bank]] <ref>11 July 2010 IOM Gov website – Press Release from the Chief Secretary’s Office http://www.gov.im/cso/viewnews.gov?page=lib/news/cso/initiativeishelp.xml {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009060824/http://www.gov.im/cso/viewnews.gov?page=lib%2Fnews%2Fcso%2Finitiativeishelp.xml# |date=9 October 2012 }}</ref> the [[Commonwealth Secretariat]], and the [[Small States Network for Economic Development]].<ref>11 July 2010 IOM Gov website – Press Release from the Chief Secretary’s Office http://www.gov.im/cso/viewnews.gov?page=lib/news/cso/initiativeishelp.xml {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009060824/http://www.gov.im/cso/viewnews.gov?page=lib%2Fnews%2Fcso%2Finitiativeishelp.xml# |date=9 October 2012 }}</ref> Initial funding was provided by the Isle of Man Government.
The Centre’s inaugural nine-day programme, designed and directed by Ron Emerson<ref>27 August 2009 Isle of Man News Initiative will help small countries respond to financial crisis http://www.iomguide.com/news/general-news.php?story=104779 Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> took place in September 2009 at both the Isle of Man International Business School and Oxford University,<ref>11 July 2010 BBC News Isle of Man https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10590440</ref> and continues,<ref>18 October 2010 Manx Radio - Island earns recognition at ‘highest level’ http://www.manxradio.com/newsread.aspx?id=48056{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> covering key issues such as risk assessment, management and regulation, debt and cash management, and regulatory collaboration.<ref>World Bank Projects and Operations - http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/PROJECTS/0,,contentMDK:22284517~pagePK:41367~piPK:51533~theSitePK:40941,00.html Accessed 20 April 2011</ref> The 2011 Programme was held in the [[Isle of Man]] and at [[St Catherine's College, Oxford]] and was directed by Alison McQuater.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
* Official Site [http://www.scfmc.im] * Isle of Man Financial Supervision Commission [http://www.gov.im/fsc] * Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) [http://www.oecd.org] * Small States Network for Economic Development [http://www.ssned.org] * World Bank [http://www.worldbank.org]
<!--- Categories --->
[[Category:International economic organizations]] [[Category:Economic development organizations]] [[Category:Organisations based in the Isle of Man]]

<!-- [[File:SNVI Logo 6.svg|thumbnail|right|]] --> '''SONACOME''' (Société Nationale de Construction Mecanique) is an [[Algeria|Algerian]] construction equipment maker.
Established in Algiers in 1967, the company has produced an off road vehicle for the [[Dakar Rally]].
[[SNVI]], a truck manufacturer, is a subsidiary.
== Products ==
* M210 transport truck * C260 transport truck * b350 transport truck * K66 dump truck * K120 transport truck * K66 transport truck * 49V8 Autocar * 100v8 Autobus * Safir Autocar * 100 l6 Autobus
[[Category:Truck manufacturers]] [[Category:Construction equipment manufacturers]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of Algeria]] [[Category:Companies of Algeria]] [[Category:Vehicle manufacturing companies established in 1957]] [[Category:Algerian brands]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Algeria]]

The '''St. Teodora de la Sihla Church''' ({{lang-ro|Biserica Sfânta Teodora de la Sihla}}) is a cathedral in [[Central Chişinău]], [[Moldova]].
== Overview ==
Formerly the chapel of a girls gymnasium, the church of [[Theodora of Sihla|St. Teodora de la Sihla]] is an architectural masterpiece{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} by [[Alexander Bernardazzi]]. It boasts the elements of his favorite neoclassic [[byzantine architecture]].
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Capela Gimnaziului de Fete.jpg File:St. Teodora de la Sihla Church, Chişinău.jpg| </gallery>
== See also == * [[Metropolis of Bessarabia]]
== External links == {{Commons category|St. Teodora de la Sihla Church}} * [http://www.monument.sit.md/biserici/puskin-20/ Puşkin, 20 A, Sf. Cuvioasa Teodora de la Sihla] * [http://www.monument.md/arhitectura_religioasa/biserici_piatra/6/ Biserica Sfânta Teodora de la Sihla, Chişinău]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = The Gentle Indifference of the World | image = The Gentle Indifference of the World.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Adilkhan Yerzhanov]] | producer = | writer = Adilkhan Yerzhanov
[[Roelof Jan Minneboo]] | starring = [[Adiya Mussina]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{film date|2018|5|17|[[2018 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]]|df=yes}} | runtime = | country = Kazakhstan | language = Kazakh | budget = }} '''''The Gentle Indifference of the World''''' is a 2018 Kazakhstani [[drama film]] directed by [[Adilkhan Yerzhanov]]. It was screened in the [[Un Certain Regard]] section at the [[2018 Cannes Film Festival]].{{citeweb|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/infos-communiques/communique/articles/the-2018-official-selection|title=The 2018 Official Selection|work=Cannes|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{citeweb|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/cannes-lineup-includes-new-films-from-spike-lee-jean-luc-godard-1202751300/|title=Cannes Lineup Includes New Films From Spike Lee, Jean-Luc Godard|work=Variety|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ==Cast== * [[Adiya Mussina]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|8269378|The Gentle Indifference of the World}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gentle Indifference Of The World, The}} [[Category:2018 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Kazakhstani films]] [[Category:Kazakh-language films]] {{Kazakhstan-film-stub}} {{2010s-drama-film-stub}}
